audience: Mid-career professionals seeking management credentials without full-time commitment
audienceConstraints: 2–3 hours/week commitment; work experience 5+ years; geographically dispersed
valueProposition: Accredited QQI Level 9; hybrid delivery; applied, peer-learning cohort model
deliveryStructure: 12-week semesters (Spring & Autumn); 2-hour live sessions weekly; weekly async work; monthly intensive (optional)

capabilities.label: Strategic Leadership
capabilities.description: Apply strategic frameworks to analysate and influence organisational direction

capabilities.label: Ethical Decision-Making
capabilities.description: Make principled decisions in complex, ambiguous contexts with stakeholder consideration

capabilities.label: Data-Driven Insight
capabilities.description: Interpret quantitative and qualitative data to inform management decisions

capabilities.label: Team & Organisational Development
capabilities.description: Design and facilitate change initiatives and build high-performing teams

capabilities.label: Global Perspectives
capabilities.description: Understand and navigate cross-cultural and international dimensions of business

capabilities.label: Professional Communication
capabilities.description: Articulate management ideas clearly to diverse audiences (written, oral, visual)

differentiators: Case-study driven curriculum rooted in participants' sectors
Monthly in-person intensives allowing live labs and team projects
Industry guest lecturers and real consultancy projects
Integrated ethics and sustainability throughout (not siloed)
Flexible electives allowing specialization (e.g., HR, Finance, Operations)

draftPLOs.statement: Analyse complex organisational challenges using established frameworks (e.g., PESTLE, Porter's 5 Forces, balanced scorecard) and synthesise solutions incorporating financial, ethical, and sustainability dimensions.
Evaluate leadership approaches in light of organisational culture, stakeholder needs, and ethical principles, and propose context-appropriate strategies for team and organisational development.
Interpret quantitative and qualitative data from business systems (e.g., financial statements, survey data, market research) and communicate actionable insights to diverse audiences.
Design and implement a management project (change initiative, process improvement, or strategy) within an organisational context, leveraging communication, collaboration, and critical reflection.

assessmentPortfolio.title: Organisational Analysis Case Study
assessmentPortfolio.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Randomised case studies; Turnitin check; live viva follow-up for borderline grades

assessmentPortfolio.title: Group Strategy Project & Live Presentation
assessmentPortfolio.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Live synchronous Q&A; individual oral component; peer assessment of contributions; video recording for attendance evidence

assessmentPortfolio.title: Reflective Learning Portfolio
evidenceOutputs: 5 curated artefacts (essay snippets, project outputs, reflections)
assessmentPortfolio.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Live viva component; require specific evidence from formative assessments; tutor verification of authorship

assessmentPortfolio.title: Continuous Participation & Online Discussion
evidenceOutputs: Reflection on learning from peer engagement (500 words)
assessmentPortfolio.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Rubric-based grading of engagement depth (not volume); required evidence of critical synthesis; tutor spot-checks for AI content

assessmentPortfolio.title: Data Analysis & Visualisation Assignment
assessmentPortfolio.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Live code walkthrough; peer review of methodology; data provided to randomise outcomes
feedbackMoments: Summative feedback on analysis quality & insight

learningExperience.description: Weekly rhythm for a hybrid, part-time cohort. Each week includes synchronous and asynchronous touchpoints.

weeklyTemplate.wednesdayEvening: Sync (2hr live session [UTC]): Case discussion, small-group breakouts, live polling, Q&A. Recording provided within 24hr.
weeklyTemplate.thursday: Async: Forum opens; students post initial thoughts + questions (peer engagement begins)
weeklyTemplate.friday: Async: Students consolidate learning; post substantive replies to peers
weeklyTemplate.weekend: Async: Tutor posts synthesis; curates exemplar contributions; flags next week's focus
weeklyTemplate.repeatingCycles: Formative mini-quiz mid-week (self-check); tutor office hour Friday 5–6pm (optional, drop-in)

principles: Apply: Use case/data in live session breakouts
Discuss: Peer exchange in forums; live debates in sync sessions
Produce: Individual reflection or group outputs due before next cycle
Feedback: Peer + tutor + self-assessment integrated throughout

coiPlan.description: Community of Inquiry presence mapped to 12-week delivery.

teachingPresence: Announcement: Welcome & ground rules
Live session: Introductions & cohort contract (75 min, plus 15 min social)
socialPresence: Optional: Social breakout rooms (5 min at end of live session)

teachingPresence: Micro-lecture: PESTLE & Porter's 5 Forces
Live session: Framework application to sector case studies
socialPresence: Triads assigned (3 people per group for semester); icebreaker task

teachingPresence: Feedback on Week 1 forum contributions (tutor summary)
Live session: Ethics case workshop + stakeholder mapping
socialPresence: Peer triad check-in (10 min, mid-live session)

teachingPresence: Live session: Project brief, group assignment, team collaboration norms
cognitivePresence: Trigger: Real org challenge to solve

teachingPresence: Micro-lecture: Data interpretation & choice of visualisation
Live session: Guest speaker (data-driven decision making)
socialPresence: Peer feedback exchange (data analysis drafts, within triads)
cognitivePresence: Exploration: Analysis methods in breakout rooms

weeks.theme: Mid-Semester Intensive (in-person or extended sync day)
teachingPresence: 8-hour day: Lab sessions, industry consultancy project pitches, tutor office hours
cognitivePresence: Resolution: Real feedback on consultancy projects

teachingPresence: Feedback on case study outlines (Week 5 submission)
Live session: Change frameworks & resistance dialogue
Micro-lecture: Communication models
Live session: Presentation coaching + dry-run (volunteer groups)
socialPresence: Cohort social (20 min at start of live session)

teachingPresence: Live session: Portfolio guidelines, exemplar walkthrough
Tutor office hour: Portfolio queries
socialPresence: Peer triads: Share curated portfolio artefacts (async, 3-day window)

teachingPresence: Live session (2x, staggered): Group presentations + live Q&A
Recorded for async viewing
Micro-lecture: Integrating frameworks across semester
Office hour: Individual viva prep
socialPresence: Peer viva practice (volunteer pairs, forum exchange)

teachingPresence: Portfolio vivas (individual, individual scheduling)
Closing celebration (live session, 90 min: debrief + goodbye)

learningOutcomes.statement: Apply established strategic analysis frameworks (PESTLE, Porter's 5 Forces, balanced scorecard) to evaluate organisational environments and competitive positioning
Analyse internal and external factors influencing strategic choices, incorporating financial, ethical, and sustainability considerations
Synthesise strategic recommendations for complex organisational scenarios, articulated clearly to diverse stakeholders

assessments.name: Case Study Analysis: Organisational Strategy
assessments.description: Analyse a real or realistic organisation using strategic frameworks. 2500 words. Includes PESTLE, competitive positioning, recommended strategic shifts, and ethical considerations.
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Randomised case studies; Turnitin check; live viva follow-up for >5% flagged content; peer review encourages original interpretation

assessments.name: Strategic Framework Application Quiz
assessments.description: Scenario-based quiz (timed, 45 min). Students apply frameworks to new situations in real-time. Auto-graded.
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Timed in-class environment; immediate grading; cannot use external tools

assessments.name: Peer Review & Forum Participation
assessments.description: Weekly forum posts analysing case snippets. Minimum 300 words + substantive replies to 2 peers. Rubric emphasises critical synthesis over volume.
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Rubric-based depth assessment; tutor spot-checks for AI markers; peer review of engagement quality

udlEvidence.evidence: Module provides case studies in multiple formats: written text, video interviews with executives, infographic summaries, and interactive dashboards. Students choose preferred modality for engagement.
Strategic terminology glossary embedded in LMS. Key concepts introduced with plain-language definitions, field examples, and visual concept maps. Weekly terminology quiz reinforces vocabulary.
Learners can respond to assessment prompts via written essay, recorded presentation, annotated visual map, or live discussion. Choice of format available for both formative and summative.
Case studies drawn from students' own industries. Guest speakers (industry practitioners) add relevance. Peer learning cohort ensures personal connections and accountability.

weeklyTemplate.monday: Release: Case brief + reading list; optional 'theory checkpoint' video (12 min); glossary updated
weeklyTemplate.wednesdayEvening: Live session (2hr): Framework walkthrough via live case breakout analysis; triads analyse simultaneously; tutor synthesises insights
weeklyTemplate.thursday: Forum opens: Students post initial strategic appraisal of case (250+ words). Peer replies encouraged.
weeklyTemplate.friday: Async work: Students refine draft analysis; access curated peer examples; optional office hour Q&A
weeklyTemplate.weekend: Tutor synthesis posted: Key patterns noted; exemplar contributions highlighted; preview of next week's framework

learningOutcomes.statement: Evaluate leadership approaches in light of organisational culture, stakeholder needs, and ethical principles
Design and justify ethical decision-making frameworks for ambiguous organisational scenarios
Propose context-appropriate change management and stakeholder engagement strategies for team and organisational development

assessments.name: Ethical Dilemma Response & Group Debate
assessments.description: Individual written position (1500 words) on assigned ethical scenario + live group debate (30 min). Students argue competing ethical frameworks. Video recorded.
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Live synchronous debate element prevents AI generation; individual position requires personal justification; Turnitin checks on written component

assessments.name: Change Management Plan
assessments.description: Small group (3 people) design a change initiative for a real org challenge. Deliverable: 3000-word plan + stakeholder analysis matrix. Individual reflection on group contribution (500 words).
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Peer-rated individual contributions (20% weighting); group viva (15 min); individual reflection demonstrates personal thinking

assessments.name: Reflective Practice Journal
assessments.description: Weekly reflective entries (2-3 weeks selected) on leadership moments from practice. Ungraded; counts toward participation credit.
assessments.aiRiskDesignMitigation: Personal reflection on contextual experience; highly individualised; difficult to AI-generate authentically

udlEvidence.evidence: Leadership theories introduced via live case discussion, then anchored to students' own organisational contexts. Prior knowledge activated through icebreaker interviews.
Assessment options include written response, video presentation, or live spoken debate. Synchronous component accessible async via recordings.
Peer feedback embedded throughout; group work provides social accountability; tutor recognises exemplar contributions publicly in forum

weeklyTemplate.monday: Release: Leadership framework overview (micro-lecture, 15 min); ethical case prompt
weeklyTemplate.wednesdayEvening: Live session (2hr): Guest speaker (senior leader) discusses real ethical challenge; breakout debates on frameworks; live Q&A
weeklyTemplate.thursday: Forum: Students post ethical position statement; peer replies challenge reasoning
weeklyTemplate.friday: Async work: Access exemplar debate transcripts; draft change plan with group members (collaborative doc)
weeklyTemplate.weekend: Tutor synthesis: Integrate ethics with strategy; flag common misconceptions; set up next week's organisational scenario

risksAndAssumptions.risk: Asynchronous participation: Weak engagement in forum if students feel isolated or unsupported
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Expect 60–70% student participation within first 2 weeks; may drop if tutor feedback delays >3 days
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Tutor commitment: 48-hr max turnaround on forum posts first 4 weeks; template responses for common questions; weekly exemplar & recognition

risksAndAssumptions.risk: Timezone challenges: Cohort spans 2–3 time zones (US East, UK, Europe); live sessions can't suit all
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Async video recording + interactive tools (polls, breakouts) will mitigate; retention of part-time cohorts ~80–85%
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Rotate live session time (semester 1: 8pm UK = 3pm ET; semester 2: 7pm UK = 2pm ET); record all sessions within 24 hr; async breakout alternatives

risksAndAssumptions.risk: AI content detection: Students tempted to use generative AI for essays/case-study analysis, evading authenticity
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Turnitin + live viva will catch ~90% detectable AI; peer review + rubric emphasis on 'evidence' reduces incentive
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Rubric emphasises unique interpretation, not 'analysis'; Turnitin checks flagged submissions; viva for any >10% flagged; portfolio includes process artefacts

risksAndAssumptions.risk: Group project dynamics: Free-riding or conflict in 4-person groups could torpedo engagement & fairness
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Cohort self-selects for professionalism; peer feedback + individual viva component ensures accountability; ~5% may still struggle
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Team contract in Week 1; peer-rated contributions (weighted 20% vs 80% group grade); tutor mediation protocol; individual oral component (15 min, individual weighting)

risksAndAssumptions.risk: Technical barriers: Some students may lack reliable internet, quiet workspace, or digital skills
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Part-time cohort likely has stable (mature learners), but 1–2 students may need accommodations
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Pre-programme digital literacy audit; offer in-person support slots; asynchronous alternatives for all sync components (recorded + forum threads)

risksAndAssumptions.risk: Workload creep: 10 credits assessment portfolio may feel heavy for part-time learners if tutor feedback delays accumulate
risksAndAssumptions.assumption: Well-scaffolded checkpoints + auto-save features will reduce last-minute panic; part-time cohort intrinsically motivated
risksAndAssumptions.mitigation: Clear rubrics & grade descriptors shared upfront; formative checkpoints every 2 weeks; feedback within 5 days; optional 1-1 check-ins mid-semester
